entries.title: Florida Film Festival Announces 2026 Lineup with Record Number of Local Filmmakers
entries.summary: The 35th annual Florida Film Festival reveals its spring lineup featuring over 180 films, with a spotlight on Central Florida talent.
entries.content:
The Enzian Theater has unveiled the full lineup for the 2026 Florida Film Festival, and this year's edition promises to be the most locally rooted yet. Over 40 of the 180-plus films selected were produced by Central Florida filmmakers, a record for the festival that has long served as a launchpad for independent cinema.

Festival director Matthew Curtis highlighted several world premieres, including a documentary exploring the history of Orlando's Parramore neighborhood and a narrative feature shot entirely in Winter Park. The festival will also host expanded industry panels focused on Florida's growing production infrastructure and tax incentive programs.

Tickets go on sale March 1, with early-bird passes available now through the Enzian website. The festival runs April 10-19 at the Enzian Theater and select venues across Maitland and Winter Park.
entries.author: Jessica Bryce Young

entries.title: New East End Market Food Hall Expansion Brings Five Restaurants to Audubon Park
entries.summary: East End Market completes its long-awaited expansion, adding five new vendor stalls and a rooftop bar to the Audubon Park food hall.
entries.content:
East End Market, the beloved Audubon Park food hall that has anchored the neighborhood's culinary scene since 2013, has officially opened the doors on its expansion project. The new wing adds five vendor stalls, a shared commissary kitchen, and a rooftop cocktail bar with views of the surrounding oak canopy.

Among the new tenants are Masa Ramen, helmed by a former Kadence chef bringing handmade noodles to the space, and Dulce de Orlando, a Cuban-inspired bakery from a family with deep roots in the Azalea Park community. The rooftop bar, called Canopy, focuses on Florida-sourced spirits and citrus-forward cocktails.

Market founder John Rife described the expansion as a natural evolution of the original vision: a place where local food entrepreneurs can grow without the overhead of a standalone restaurant. Weekend hours now extend to 10 PM to accommodate the rooftop bar programming.
entries.author: Brendan O'Connor

entries.title: Orlando Tech Sector Adds 3,200 Jobs in Q4 as AI Startups Cluster Along I-4 Corridor
entries.summary: Central Florida's technology sector posted strong fourth-quarter hiring numbers, driven largely by artificial intelligence and defense-tech companies.
entries.content:
The Orlando metro area added 3,200 technology jobs in the final quarter of 2025, according to new data from the Orlando Economic Partnership. The gains were concentrated in artificial intelligence, simulation, and defense technology, sectors that have historically anchored the region's tech identity but are now attracting a new wave of venture-backed startups.

Lake Nona's growing innovation district accounted for nearly a third of the new positions, with companies like Luminar Technologies and several stealth-mode AI firms expanding their Orlando footprints. The University of Central Florida's AI and machine learning programs continue to feed the local talent pipeline, graduating over 600 students in related fields last year.

Industry leaders point to Orlando's relatively affordable cost of living, proximity to defense contractors, and the modeling-and-simulation expertise built over decades at Research Park as key advantages over more saturated tech hubs.
entries.author: Richard Bilbao

entries.title: Eola Heights Night Market Returns for Its Third Season with 60 Local Vendors
entries.summary: The popular monthly night market at Lake Eola expands to 60 vendors for its 2026 season, running every second Saturday through May.
entries.content:
The Eola Heights Night Market kicks off its third season on February 8 with a roster of 60 local vendors, nearly double the count from its inaugural year. The open-air market wraps around the north shore of Lake Eola, transforming the park into a lively evening destination with live music, craft cocktails, and food from some of Orlando's most talked-about kitchens.

New additions this season include a dedicated makers row for Central Florida artisans working in ceramics, textiles, and woodworking, as well as a collaboration stage featuring performers from the Orlando Fringe community. Returning favorites include Hunger Street Tacos, La Femme du Fromage, and Skybird Juicery.

The market runs every second Saturday from 5 PM to 10 PM through May 9. Organizers have partnered with LYMMO to offer free shuttle service from the downtown parking garages to reduce congestion around the park.
entries.author: Brendan O'Connor

entries.title: Central Florida Breaks Tourism Record with 82 Million Visitors in 2025
entries.summary: Visit Orlando reports that the region welcomed 82 million visitors last year, surpassing pre-pandemic highs and setting a new all-time record.
entries.content:
Central Florida shattered its annual tourism record in 2025, welcoming an estimated 82 million visitors to the region, according to figures released by Visit Orlando. The number surpasses the previous record of 79 million set in 2024 and underscores the area's continued dominance as the most-visited destination in the United States.

Theme park investments drove much of the growth, with Universal's Epic Universe contributing significantly to visitor counts since its May 2025 opening. Walt Disney World's ongoing transformation of its EPCOT park and SeaWorld's new coaster lineup also drew strong attendance. Beyond the parks, sports tourism saw a notable boost from the 2025 Pro Bowl Games and several major esports events held at the Orange County Convention Center.

Visit Orlando president Casandra Matej noted that the challenge ahead is managing growth sustainably, with infrastructure investments in transit, housing, and hospitality workforce development at the top of the agenda for 2026.
entries.author: Gabrielle Russon

entries.title: Wekiva Springs State Park Launches Guided Full-Moon Paddle Series
entries.summary: Wekiva Springs debuts a monthly full-moon kayak and canoe paddle series running February through October 2026.
entries.content:
Wekiva Springs State Park is launching a new guided full-moon paddle series, giving visitors a chance to experience the spring-fed Wekiva River under moonlight. The program runs monthly from February through October, with the first outing scheduled for February 12, coinciding with the full Snow Moon.

Park rangers and volunteer naturalists will lead groups of up to 30 paddlers on a 3-mile round trip from the main spring head downstream through cypress-lined corridors. Participants can expect to spot owls, bats, and the occasional alligator basking on the banks. Kayak and canoe rentals are available on-site, though experienced paddlers are welcome to bring their own craft.

Registration is required and spots have been filling quickly. The $25 per-person fee covers the guided experience and park entry after hours. The series is part of a broader Florida State Parks initiative to expand nighttime programming and connect visitors with natural Florida beyond daylight hours.
entries.author: Kate Santich

entries.title: Mills 50 District Celebrates Lunar New Year with Weekend Street Festival
entries.summary: Orlando's Mills 50 Vietnamese-American district hosts a two-day Lunar New Year celebration with food, performances, and a dragon parade.
entries.content:
The Mills 50 district, home to one of the largest Vietnamese-American communities in the Southeast, is hosting its annual Lunar New Year street festival on February 14-15 to welcome the Year of the Horse. Colonial Drive between Mills Avenue and Bumby Avenue will close to traffic for the two-day celebration, which draws tens of thousands of visitors each year.

The festival features a traditional dragon and lion dance parade, martial arts demonstrations, live music spanning Vietnamese folk and contemporary genres, and a street food market with offerings from over 25 local restaurants. Highlights include banh mi competitions, pho eating contests, and a lantern-lighting ceremony at dusk on Saturday.

Mills 50 Main Street District director Somy Ali emphasized the festival's role in sharing Vietnamese culture with the broader Orlando community. Free parking is available at Fashion Square Mall with complimentary shuttle service to the festival grounds.
entries.address: Colonial Dr & Mills Ave, Orlando, FL 32803
entries.author: Faiyaz Kara

entries.title: Wall Street Plaza Announces Major Renovation and New Concept Bars for Downtown Nightlife
entries.summary: The iconic Wall Street Plaza entertainment complex reveals a multi-million dollar renovation plan that will add three new concept bars by summer 2026.
entries.content:
Wall Street Plaza, the downtown Orlando nightlife institution that has anchored the Wall Street entertainment corridor for over two decades, is undergoing its most significant renovation since opening. Owner and operator Wall St. Entertainment Group announced a multi-phase project that will refresh existing venues and introduce three entirely new concept bars by June 2026.

The new additions include a mezcal-focused cocktail bar, a retro arcade bar with over 50 classic cabinets, and a speakeasy-style jazz lounge tucked behind a hidden entrance on Court Avenue. The renovation also brings infrastructure upgrades including improved sound systems, expanded outdoor seating, and a new pedestrian-friendly courtyard connecting the venues.

The project comes as downtown Orlando's nightlife scene experiences a resurgence, with several new bars and restaurants opening along Church Street and Orange Avenue in recent months. Construction is already underway, with the first new venue expected to soft-open in April.
entries.author: Cameron Meier

entries.title: Orlando City SC Opens New State-of-the-Art Training Facility in Osceola County
entries.summary: Orlando City Soccer Club unveils its new $80 million training campus in Kissimmee, featuring six full-size pitches and a sports science center.
entries.content:
Orlando City SC officially cut the ribbon on its new training facility in Osceola County, a sprawling $80 million campus that represents the club's largest infrastructure investment to date. The complex includes six full-size natural grass pitches, a FIFA-standard synthetic turf field, a hydrotherapy recovery center, and a sports science wing equipped with motion capture and biomechanical analysis tools.

The facility will serve as the permanent training home for both the MLS first team and Orlando City B, the club's developmental squad competing in MLS NEXT Pro. A dedicated youth academy building will also host the club's expanding pipeline of Central Florida talent, with capacity to train up to 200 academy players annually.

Osceola County officials highlighted the economic impact, projecting the facility will generate over $15 million annually in local spending and position the region as a hub for professional and international soccer events. The campus is expected to host visiting national teams preparing for tournaments at nearby venues.
entries.author: Julia Poe

entries.title: UCF Downtown Campus Launches Free Community Tech Workshop Series
entries.summary: UCF's downtown campus partners with local nonprofits to offer free coding, cybersecurity, and AI literacy workshops open to all Central Florida residents.
entries.content:
The University of Central Florida's downtown campus is rolling out a free community technology workshop series starting in February, aimed at bridging the digital skills gap across Central Florida. The program, developed in partnership with Code Orlando and the Orlando Urban League, offers hands-on sessions in web development, cybersecurity fundamentals, and AI literacy for beginners.

Workshops meet twice weekly on Tuesday and Thursday evenings from 6 PM to 8 PM at UCF's downtown campus in the Creative Village district. No prior experience is required, and participants receive a certificate of completion after finishing any 8-week track. Instructors include UCF faculty, industry professionals, and volunteer mentors from local tech companies.

UCF Downtown dean Stella Sung described the series as part of the university's commitment to being an anchor institution for the surrounding community. Registration is open on the UCF Downtown website, and childcare is available on-site at no cost to participants.
entries.author: Maria Torres
